theories.card_other: Atoms arranged in regular, repeating pattern (crystal lattice). Long-range order. Sharp melting point. Examples: metals, salt, diamond. Show anisotropy (properties vary with direction). Most solids are crystalline.

Atoms arranged randomly without long-range order. Like frozen liquid. Gradual softening instead of sharp melting. Examples: glass, plastics, rubber. Isotropic properties. Sometimes called supercooled liquids.

Smallest repeating unit of crystal lattice. Contains atoms in specific arrangement. Entire crystal built by repeating unit cell. Defined by lattice parameters (lengths and angles). Seven crystal systems exist.

Three-dimensional regular arrangement of atoms/ions/molecules. Mathematical points representing atom positions. Characterized by symmetry. Determines many properties (mechanical, optical, electrical).
Force per unit area applied to material. SI unit: pascal (Pa) or N/m². Types: tensile (pulling), compressive (pushing), shear (parallel). Symbol: σ. Causes deformation.
Relative deformation in response to stress. Dimensionless (ratio of change to original). Types: longitudinal (length change), volumetric (volume change), shear (shape change). Symbol: ε.
Temporary deformation. Material returns to original shape when stress removed. Obeys Hooke's law (stress ∝ strain). Bonds stretched but not broken. Occurs below elastic limit.
Permanent deformation. Material does not return to original shape. Occurs beyond elastic limit. Atoms move to new positions. Used in metal forming (forging, rolling).

Stress proportional to strain within elastic limit. Linear region on stress-strain curve. Constant of proportionality is elastic modulus. Valid for small deformations. Beyond elastic limit, material yields.
Measure of material's stiffness or resistance to deformation. Ratio of stress to strain. Higher modulus means stiffer material. SI unit: pascal (Pa). Three types: Young's, bulk, shear.
Resistance to longitudinal stress (stretching/compression). Y = (F/A)/(ΔL/L). Measures stiffness. Steel has high Y, rubber has low Y. Used in structural engineering. Symbol: Y or E.
Resistance to uniform compression (volume change). K = -ΔP/(ΔV/V). Reciprocal is compressibility. Measures how incompressible material is. Liquids and solids have high K, gases low K. Symbol: K or B.
Resistance to shear stress (parallel forces). G = (F/A)/(Δx/h). Measures resistance to shape change at constant volume. Only applies to solids. Fluids have zero shear modulus. Symbol: G.

Maximum stress material can withstand and still return to original shape. Beyond this, permanent deformation occurs. Different from proportional limit (end of Hooke's law). Important in design safety factors.

Stress at which material begins to deform plastically. Sudden increase in strain without increase in stress. Material yields (flows). Clear in ductile materials like steel. Defines onset of permanent deformation.
Maximum stress material can withstand before breaking. Peak of stress-strain curve. After this, necking occurs (cross-section decreases). Important for material selection in engineering.
Stress at which material breaks or ruptures. End of stress-strain curve. Lower than ultimate strength for ductile materials. Equal to ultimate strength for brittle materials.

Material that can undergo significant plastic deformation before fracture. Can be drawn into wires. Long plastic region on stress-strain curve. Examples: copper, aluminum, gold. Shows necking before breaking.
Material that fractures with little or no plastic deformation. Breaks suddenly without warning. Short/no plastic region. Examples: glass, ceramics, cast iron. Dangerous in structures.
Energy stored in deformed material. Released when stress removed. Energy = ½ × stress × strain × volume. Area under stress-strain curve. Used in springs, bows.

Ratio of lateral strain to longitudinal strain. ν = -(lateral strain)/(longitudinal strain). Dimensionless, typically 0.2-0.5. Materials contract sideways when stretched. Cork ~0 (nearly incompressible), rubber ~0.5.

Explains electrical properties of solids. In crystal, atomic energy levels split into bands. Valence band (filled) and conduction band (empty/partially filled) separated by band gap. Band overlap/gap determines conductor/insulator/semiconductor.
Highest energy band filled with electrons at absolute zero. Electrons bound to atoms. In insulators/semiconductors, separated from conduction band by gap. In metals, overlaps with conduction band.
Energy band where electrons are free to move and conduct. Empty at absolute zero for insulators/semiconductors. Partially filled in metals. Electrons reaching here contribute to conductivity.
Forbidden energy region between valence and conduction bands. Large in insulators (>3 eV), small in semiconductors (~1 eV), zero in metals. Determines electrical and optical properties. Symbol: Eg.

Material with overlapping valence and conduction bands or partially filled conduction band. Free electrons available for conduction. Low resistivity. Examples: metals (copper, silver, aluminum). Conductivity decreases with temperature.
Material with large band gap (>3 eV). No free electrons at room temperature. Very high resistivity. Examples: rubber, glass, ceramics, plastics. Used for electrical isolation and safety.

Material with small band gap (~1 eV). Few free electrons at room temperature. Conductivity increases with temperature (opposite of metals). Examples: silicon, germanium. Used in electronics, solar cells.
Pure semiconductor without impurities. Equal number of electrons and holes. Conductivity low at room temperature. Increases exponentially with temperature. Fermi level at middle of band gap.
Semiconductor doped with impurities to increase conductivity. Two types: n-type (excess electrons) and p-type (excess holes). Controlled conductivity. Used in all semiconductor devices.
Doped with donor atoms (group V: P, As, Sb). Extra valence electron becomes free. Majority carriers: electrons. Minority carriers: holes. Fermi level near conduction band.
Doped with acceptor atoms (group III: B, Al, Ga). Creates holes in valence band. Majority carriers: holes. Minority carriers: electrons. Fermi level near valence band.
